segment.source: The Application Compatibility Toolkit (ACT) uses a Microsoft® SQL Server® database for storing and sharing compatibility issue data.
segment.target: The Application Compatibility Toolkit (ACT) uses a Microsoft® SQL Server® database for storing and sharing compatibility issue data.

segment.source: The Application Compatibility Toolkit (ACT) uses a Microsoft® SQL Server® database for storing and sharing compatibility issue data.
segment.target: The Application Compatibility Toolkit (ACT) uses a Microsoft® SQL Server® database for storing and sharing compatibility issue data.

segment.source: If you do not use Microsoft SQL Server, you can download and install Microsoft SQL Server Express.
segment.target: If you do not use Microsoft SQL Server, you can download and install Microsoft SQL Server Express.

segment.source: For information about creating Microsoft SQL Server databases, see Administering the Database Engine.
segment.target: For information about creating Microsoft SQL Server databases, see Administering the Database Engine.

segment.source: You can create the ACT database by using one of the following methods:
segment.target: You can create the ACT database by using one of the following methods:

segment.source: Run Application Compatibility Manager (ACM), and then use the ACT Configuration Wizard to create a new database.
segment.target: Run Application Compatibility Manager (ACM), and then use the ACT Configuration Wizard to create a new database.

segment.source: Run the CreateDB.sql file, located at %SYSTEMDRIVE%ProgramDataMicrosoftApplication Compatibility ToolkitCreateDB.sql.
segment.target: Run the CreateDB.sql file, located at %SYSTEMDRIVE%ProgramDataMicrosoftApplication Compatibility ToolkitCreateDB.sql.

segment.source: You must assign the following database roles to the following accounts.
segment.target: You must assign the following database roles to the following accounts.

segment.source: To the user and local service accounts that will run the ACT Log Processing Service (LPS), assign the dbdatareader, dbdatawriter, and dbowner database roles.
segment.target: To the user and local service accounts that will run the ACT Log Processing Service (LPS), assign the dbdatareader, dbdatawriter, and dbowner database roles.

segment.source: To the user account that will run Application Compatibility Manager (ACM), assign the dbdatareader and dbdatawriter database roles.
segment.target: To the user account that will run Application Compatibility Manager (ACM), assign the dbdatareader and dbdatawriter database roles.

segment.source: Alternatively, grant the following explicit permissions to each user that will run the ACT LPS or ACM.
segment.target: Alternatively, grant the following explicit permissions to each user that will run the ACT LPS or ACM.

segment.source: We also recommend that you make the following changes to the database as part of your deployment planning:
segment.target: We also recommend that you make the following changes to the database as part of your deployment planning:

segment.source: Create a larger database, including a larger log file–size setting, and then set the growth increments appropriately.
segment.target: Create a larger database, including a larger log file–size setting, and then set the growth increments appropriately.

segment.source: If you create a database with the default setting for data storage, the data portion of the database will have an initial size of 1 megabyte (MB), and a growth increment of 1 MB.
segment.target: If you create a database with the default setting for data storage, the data portion of the database will have an initial size of 1 megabyte (MB), and a growth increment of 1 MB.

segment.source: If you create a database with the default setting for log file storage, the log file portion of the database will have an initial size of 1 MB and a growth increment of 10 percent.
segment.target: If you create a database with the default setting for log file storage, the log file portion of the database will have an initial size of 1 MB and a growth increment of 10 percent.

segment.source: We recommend that you maintain a data-to-log file ratio of 5:1 or 4:1.
segment.target: We recommend that you maintain a data-to-log file ratio of 5:1 or 4:1.

segment.source: For example, if your data portion is 5 gigabytes (GB), your log file portion should be 1 GB.
segment.target: For example, if your data portion is 5 gigabytes (GB), your log file portion should be 1 GB.

segment.source: Change the recovery model of your database.
segment.target: Change the recovery model of your database.

segment.source: The default recovery model is Full, but we recommend that you change the recovery model to Simple to improve performance and reduce disk space requirements.
segment.target: The default recovery model is Full, but we recommend that you change the recovery model to Simple to improve performance and reduce disk space requirements.

segment.source: Store the data portion and log file portion of your ACT database on separate hard drives.
segment.target: Store the data portion and log file portion of your ACT database on separate hard drives.

segment.source: Unless otherwise specified by your SQL Administrator, the default is for the data and log files to be stored on the same hard drive.
segment.target: Unless otherwise specified by your SQL Administrator, the default is for the data and log files to be stored on the same hard drive.

segment.source: We recommend separating the data from the log files to reduce disk I/O contention.
segment.target: We recommend separating the data from the log files to reduce disk I/O contention.
